Will a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war before January 1, 2025?


TODAY'S DATE:

RESOLUTION CRITERIA:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if there is any nuclear detonation as an act of war before January 1, 2025.  Resolution will be by credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify (see fine print). Attacks using [strategic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_nuclear_weapon) and [tactical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tactical_nuclear_weapon) nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.

ADDITIONAL CRITERIA:
[Barrett et al. 2013](http://scienceandglobalsecurity.org/archive/sgs21barrett.pdf) defined terms to distinguish between causes of nuclear detonations:

>In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders.

>In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.

>In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.

BACKGROUND:
In the last 75 years, two nuclear weapons have been detonated as an act of war; the [bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki) in 1945, at the end of WWII. Despite tensions being high between the US and the USSR during the Cold War, and [several close calls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_close_calls), there have been no additional nuclear weapons detonated as acts of war. 

Currently, estimated nuclear weapon stockpiles are 15,000 warheads worldwide, mostly in the US and Russia, and there are eight or nine states that possess nuclear weapons (China, France, Russia, United Kingdom, United States, India, North Korea, Pakistan, and [Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Israel) which remains officially ambiguous). The use of these nuclear weapons [could be catastrophic](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/1494/ragnar%25C3%25B6k-question-series-if-a-global-catastrophe-occurs-will-it-be-due-to-nuclear-war/).

The TPNW, which entered into force on January 22, 2021, prohibits the development, testing, production, acquisition, possession, stockpiling, use, or threat of use of nuclear weapons. However, it is important to note that none of the nuclear-armed states have signed or ratified this treaty, and many have expressed opposition to it.

## Historical Context and Current State
Historically, there have been no nuclear detonations in acts of war since the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945. The Cuban Missile Crisis in 1962 was a close call, but it did not result in any nuclear detonations. Recent years have seen increased tensions between nuclear-armed states, but no nuclear weapons have been used in conflict.

Current geopolitical tensions, particularly between nations like the United States, Russia, India, and Pakistan, remain high. However, despite these tensions, there has been no recent instance of a nuclear weapon being detonated in an act of war. The expansion of nuclear arsenals in countries like India and Pakistan increases the risk, but it does not guarantee an event.

## Base Rates
The base rate for nuclear detonations in acts of war is extremely low. Since 1945, there have been no instances of nuclear weapons being used in conflict, despite several close calls and ongoing nuclear proliferation.

## International Efforts
International efforts, such as the TPNW and other disarmament initiatives, aim to reduce the risk of nuclear war. However, the effectiveness of these efforts is limited by the lack of participation from nuclear-armed states.

## Community Predictions
Community predictions on platforms like Metaculus indicate a low probability of a nuclear detonation in an act of war. For example, a question about whether there would be any non-test nuclear detonations by January 1, 2024, resolved as "Yes" (meaning no such detonations occurred), with a community prediction of 99%.

Given this information, while it is impossible to rule out the possibility entirely, the historical base rate and current international efforts suggest that the likelihood of a nuclear weapon being detonated as an act of war before January 1, 2025, is relatively low. However, this does not mean it is impossible, and ongoing geopolitical tensions and the expansion of nuclear arsenals are factors that need to be considered.
